summary: This document is an email chain from September 2019 discussing federal statute of limitation reform for childhood sexual abuse survivors, prompted by the passage of New York's Child Victims Act. It includes an op-ed by Theresa Covington calling for a federal Child Victims Act, referencing the cases of Jeffrey Epstein and Larry Nassar as catalysts for the national conversation.

persons.name: Theresa Covington
persons.role: Author of Op-Ed, Director of Within Our Reach office
persons.context: Author of the New York Daily News op-ed calling for a federal Child Victims Act, citing the Epstein and Nassar cases. She served on the Commission to Eliminate Child Abuse and Neglect Fatalities.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced in the op-ed as a high-profile case that brought child sexual abuse into the national dialogue. Mentioned regarding his lenient 2008 non-prosecution agreement and 13-month jail sentence.

persons.name: Larry Nassar
persons.context: Referenced alongside Epstein as a high-profile case of child sexual abuse. Mentioned in relation to a congressional report that found multiple institutions failed to stop his abuse.

persons.name: Simone Biles
persons.context: Quoted in the op-ed criticizing USA Gymnastics for failing to protect athletes from abuse, in the context of the Nassar case.

persons.name: Michael Polenberg
persons.role: Vice President, Government Affairs at Safe Horizon
persons.context: His contact information is appended to the forwarded op-ed. He is associated with Safe Horizon, a victim services organization.

persons.name: Jimmy
persons.context: Introduced in the email chain as Safe Horizon's Policy Director, who moved into that position earlier in the summer of 2019.

connections.description: Covington references Epstein's case in her op-ed as a key example driving the need for federal statute of limitation reform.
Covington references Nassar's case alongside Epstein's as catalysts for the national dialogue on child sexual abuse.
Biles is referenced as a victim criticizing the institutions (like USA Gymnastics) that enabled Nassar's abuse.
Both are associated with Safe Horizon, a victim services organization, as indicated in the email chain.

events.title: Epstein's Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: A lenient federal non-prosecution agreement resulted in Epstein serving only 13 months in jail, with daily work release, and had more serious charges wiped clean.

events.title: Passage of NY Child Victims Act
events.description: New York State passed the Child Victims Act, greatly extending statutes of limitations for sex crimes, allowing victims to file civil suits until age 55 and opening a one-year look-back window.

events.title: Publication of Op-Ed
events.description: Theresa Covington's op-ed 'We need a federal Child Victims Act' was published in the New York Daily News, calling for federal statute of limitation reform.

events.title: Commission Report Release
events.description: The Commission to Eliminate Child Abuse and Neglect Fatalities, on which Theresa Covington served, released its report calling for a multidisciplinary approach to child protection.

keyFacts: The email discusses renewed interest in federal statute of limitation reform for childhood sexual abuse survivors following New York's passage of the Child Victims Act in January 2019.
The attached op-ed explicitly cites the Jeffrey Epstein and Larry Nassar cases as high-profile examples that have brought child sexual abuse into the national dialogue.
The op-ed details Epstein's 2008 non-prosecution agreement, which resulted in only 13 months in jail with work release and the wiping clean of more serious charges.
The op-ed calls for a federal law to enable victims, regardless of their state, to have the opportunity to face their abuser in court.
The correspondence involves staff from Safe Horizon, a victim services organization, discussing policy guidance on federal statute of limitations.
